content.description:
How Gods and Heroes Travel

Qualis ubi hibernamhibernus, -a, -um, adj.: wintry LyciamLycia, -ae, f.: Lycia (a region in Asia Minor) XanthiXanthus, -i, m.: Xanthus (a river in Troy)que fluentafluentum, -i, n. = flumen, -inis 
deserit ac DelumDelos, -i, f.: Delos (an island in the Cyclades) maternammaternus, -a, -um, adj.: of a mother invisitinviso, -ere = visito, -are Apollo, 
frondefrons, frondis, f.: garland premit crinemcrinis, -is, m. = coma, -ae fingens atque implicat auro, 
tela sonant umeris: haud illo segniorsegnis, -e, adj. = tardus, -a, -um ibat 

Line 5Aeneas.
content.question: In lines 4-5, haud illo segnior ibat Aeneas is translated

choices.label: he was going slower than Aeneas
Aeneas was not walking that slow
that Aeneas was going there more slowly
Aeneas was not going slower than that one was

content.answer: Aeneas was not going slower than that one was

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2
